newsitem.title: GERMANY: German DAX ends firm, chemical sector supports.
newsitem.headline: German DAX ends firm, chemical sector supports.

text.p: Germany's DAX index of 30 leading shares posted modest gains on Thursday as selective interest in the chemical sector continued and the Bundesbank's decision to leave rates unchanged matched expectations.
The 30-share DAX rose 6.14 points to end the bourse session at 3,104.14 points.
But prices were lower than the close of after-bourse screen trading on Wednesday, during which shares staged a mini-rally on early Wall Street gains, which were later reversed.
"All in all this is a consolidation," said one dealer, who said he expected little movement through the rest of the day.
"There is no concerted push upward but the dollar is still over 1.65 and that is still a positive."
The dollar was buoyed by a report showing a sharp rise in German jobless data in January, when unemployment hit 4.66 million -- the highest level since the 1930s.

The chemical sector was ahead for the second day in a row, with the DAX-100 chemical sector index up 0.6 percent, rising three times faster than the top 100 shares. Dealers say chemicals are catching up now after lagging the DAX for months.

The engineering sector was even more in demand after better-than-expected year-end earnings from Preussag AG and a decision to hold its dividend at 12 marks, countering some market fears that the payout would be cut.
After an initial surge which flagged as trading continued, Preussag ended floor dealings up three marks at 391.
Engineering group Mannesmann rose 14.50 marks to 658 after Merrill Lynch raised the stock to a "buy" from "neutral" and, according to dealers, raised its target price for the stock significantly.

Software group SAP's preferred shares slipped 4.70 marks to 249.80 after a placement at 244 marks of some 3.54 million common shares once held by SAP's co-founder Hans-Werner Hector, who resigned in late 1996.
The Bundesbank's largely-expected decision to leave interest rates unchanged had minimal impact on the market.
Dealers generally see no immediate impetus for a move on rates and one noted: "With this kind of jobless rate, we can more or less rule out a rate hike."
